thread.title: How the North East voted in the EU referendum compared to the rest of the country
thread.title_full: How the North East voted in the EU referendum compared to the rest of the country

author: Matt McKenzie
title: How the North East voted in the EU referendum compared to the rest of the country
text:
How the North East voted in the EU referendum compared to the rest of the country 08:41, 24 Jun 2016 08:41, 24 Jun 2016 By Matt McKenzie The region voted in favour of leaving the European Union - but how do our numbers compare to elsewhere? Shares Get daily news by email A map showing the EU vote at 6am on June 24 
The North East emphatically turned its back on the EU , with a whopping 58% voting for a Brexit in the referendum. 
In all, 1.34 million of us turned out to vote across the region - with 778,103 siding with leave and 562,595 with remain, meaning a resounding victory. 
Every North East authority beside Newcastle - which only marginally voted remain - bolted for the exit door. 
As night melted into early morning, the results for Leave continued to file in; South Tyneside with 62%, Hartlepool with 69%, Middlesbrough with 65%, Stockton-on-Tees with 61%, Redcar with 66%, North Tyneside with 53%, Darlington with 56%, Gateshead with 56%, Durham with 57% and Northumberland with 54%. 
But how do our numbers compare with other parts of the UK? 
To help you put it in perspective, weâ€™ve collated some key results below: NEWCASTLE
